reviewText: Turba takes the enticing idea of a Bejeweled-style game that utilizes your music library and screws it all up by incorporating features that don't work as they should, resulting in a nearly unplayable mess. The simple task of matching three or more blocks of the same color is complicated by bomb" blocks
date: which are blocks that will cause a 3x3 set of blocks to turn gray if they aren't matched within a certain number of beats. Adding to this problem is the brainless design decision that your board fills up with blocks with each beat of the song. This ensures that fast songs are literally unbeatable on certain play modes
recommended: even without the addition of bomb blocks. Worse yet
hoursPlayed: the game does not accurately detect beats
voteText: so blocks appear at completely random intervals. Finally
helpfulPercent: cheaters have devised a way to obtain the top scores on literally every song
votesHelpful: so forget about ranking in the top 3 on anything
votesTotal: no matter how obscure it is. I've spoken with one of the devs (They have another terrible-looking game on Greenlight)
votesFunny: and he sees nothing wrong with the game and has no plans to support it any further. This game is a horrendous waste of money at any price."

reviewText: Good concept, terrible execution. Beat detection is a core gameplay element and is implemented so poorly that the game is often unplayable.

reviewText: The late 2000's gave us a cool new type of game which I like to call the media player" genre: you load up music files from your own computer and they generate the level you play
date: often with elements of a rhythm game. This fad gave us many classic games such as Beat Hazard and Audiosurf
recommended: and continues strong to this day with games like Melody's Escape and Drive Any Track. It's personally one of my favorite types of game. Unfortunately
hoursPlayed: it also gave us some real stinkers like Ugly Baby and Turba.\n\nTurba is supposed to be a rhythm-based match-3 game
voteText: but it's so ill-conceived and badly-designed on so many levels that it‚Äôs almost a work of art. The basis of the game is that you‚Äôre supposed to select groups of same-colored blocks
helpfulPercent: then right-click to clear them to the rhythm of the music. You get more points for using multiplier blocks
votesTotal: and for selecting one group of each color before clearing them at once. There are three game modes which determine how the tiles will appear: Free mode will give you a Bejeweled-style wall of blocks
votesFunny: Descend mode makes the tiles slowly push from the top of the screen like Tetris Attack
commentsCount: and Ascend mode makes tiles gradually appear on top of other tiles. To help you control the board
column16: you‚Äôre also given a choice of a rechargeable special power
column17: which ranges from generating wildcard blocks to shooting blocks with a laser. The special powers gradually unlock and grow stronger the more you play.\n\nThe game concepts are all horrible
column18: not just in practice but also in theory. For starters
column19: the core game mechanic of dragging paths through colored groups is a terrible idea. Depending on what mode you play
column20: the whole board is gradually moving
column21: and punishment tiles are decaying and causing the board to collapse. In other words
column22: the game consists of dragging paths through blocks which are always unexpectedly shifting or falling from underneath your mouse cursor. Imagine trying to draw pixel art in Microsoft Paint as the window will randomly jerk around
column23: and you can get an idea of how it feels like to play Turba. I think the idea was that you‚Äôre supposed to carefully select tiles between beats of the music
column24: but it‚Äôs ruined thanks to the beat detection.\n\nBeat detection is downright unreliable. The game‚Äôs registration of beats seems mostly random except on the most specific types of songs
column25: so it‚Äôs completely up to luck whether or not clicking on a drumbeat of the song will break your combo or keep it going. To get reasonable scores
column26: I had to find a (very) small handful of songs in my library where the beat detection actually worked and stick to those.\n\nThen you have to deal with the bombs. You cannot even rock out to your own music
column27: because the game will constantly spawn time bombs which beep obnoxiously like 90‚Äôs-era digital alarm clocks. They spawn on random tiles which must be cleared before they blow up into a 3x3 square of punishment blocks. On the higher difficulties it‚Äôs nearly impossible to get rid of them
column29: and often land in places that are unreachable anyway. Defending against bombs is not interesting and not fun
column30: not to mention that it ruins the music
column31: and I don‚Äôt see how anyone thought it was a good idea.\n\nThe menus are so badly-designed that they must be seen to be believed. They‚Äôre filled with pointless
column32: lethargic menu animations that sometimes take up to five seconds for buttons to slide into place or fade in. The selection box around items is a soft glow which is so hard to see that it might as well not be there. The menu music has some of the most depressing
column33: boring tracks I have ever heard. Whereas games like Audiosurf punch you in the face with electronica the minute you hit the title screen and get you pumped to play the game
column34: Turba‚Äôs ‚Äúsong select‚Äù menu music will forever be burned into my mind as the official theme song for watching paint dry.\n\nI‚Äôve hunted for the achievements and tried to master the gameplay
column35: and I feel like I gave Turba an honest chance at capturing my heart
column36: but it never even come close. The gameplay is just aggravating
column38: and unrewarding. The minor satisfaction I got from holding a long beat streak was destroyed by unreliable beat detection breaking my combos
column39: the massive frustration of trying to paint selection areas as the board is constantly falling and shifting
column40: and that constant beeping of the time bombs over the music that never seems to go away.\n\nBleh. Awful."

reviewText: The idea is simple yet clever - a bejeweled-like game that lets you clear the board in the rhythm of your favourite music. Sounds like fun, right? Well, it's not. The beat detection - a core part of this game mechanics - is totally screwed up which makes it pretty much unplayable.\nFirst time, I played for about an hour before I grew irritated enough to uninstall the game. Second time, I got frustrated after a few songs. Third time, I didn't even manage to finish the first song. There will be no fourth time, I'm more than sure.
voteText: 14 of 16 people (88%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Went in with low expectations, but I must say I haven't played anything this unfun in a long time.

Puzzle games with a musical/rhythmical element can turn out like Lumines -- or, at the other end of the quality spectrum, you might get Turba.

The matching mechanics are deeply, fundamentally flawed in that the game expects you to select a large number of blocks, individually (the only quick-select shortcut is so situational it's useless), precisely, in a limited time, while the level layout shifts. It takes effort to get it this wrong!

(It's also terrible from an aesthetic standpoint, but does it even matter at that point?)

reviewText:
I just played Turba for 15 minutes, to get the Summer achievement that was added to it.

Afterward when I got up from my chair, I stubbed my toe very hard, fell and bashed my arm on a bookcase as I tried to catch my fall, scraped my leg rather painfully, and finally broke my fall by smashing my hand against the sharp corner of a wooden box. My arm hurts, my leg hurts, my hand hurts, and my toe is bleeding a bit. I also seem to have punched myself in the stomach or something on the way down, I'm not even sure on that, but it hurts there too.

Still, if I had no choice but to repeat one of those two experiences, I would not choose Turba.

reviewText:
The premise of this game is great, but the execution is poor.

The feature that allows you to use music files on your computer is rendered completely ineffective by the game's inability to interpret beats for purposes of the main game mechanic of timing combos.

In fact, Turba doesn't even interpret its own beats reliably. Combined with complications introduced by exploding bomb tiles that render the playing field of the game more difficult and the unpredictable placement of tiles, this game goes beyond impressing a sense of difficulty and instead presents itself as broken and untested.

In summary, the visual aesthetics and concept are stellar, but this game is not in a state where it is fun to play.

reviewText: This USED to be a pretty good game. It's a match three puzzle game that flows to the beat of the music you put in it. In theory. The game was ok with the beat detection (which is important here because doing things on the beat is the way to succeed), but it was a little rough in spots. So they put out a patch to improve the beat detection, which just ended up wrecking it beyond repair. It's just a mess now and does not really match up to your music at all, which is the worst sin for a game based on generating content from your music. Pass on this one.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game would be passable as yet another one of those match-the-color type puzzle games, but it chooses to add an awkward beat detection system as a key point of the game's mechanics. Said system behaves incredibly unpredictably, failing to roll over the beat counter for several seconds and then suddenly shooting it forward 4 times in a single second. Doing well on a song requires playing the same song multiple times to memorize where the game detects beats". Stay away."

reviewText: A rhythm-puzzle game? Turba sounded really neat when I first saw it. I was itching to try it out. However, I was sadly disappointed.\n\nThe #1 thing that destroys this game is its abysmal beat detection. Because the rhythm of the song determines how fast the blocks spawn/move and allows you to get beat bonuses" for clearing blocks to the beat of the song
date: it's a key component of the game. Unfortunately
recommended: the game often skips beats and detects beats when there are none
hoursPlayed: completely disrupting the flow of play.\n\nA few of the other game mechanics seem a bit off as well. "Beat blocks" are supposed to turn all surrounding blocks black after they count down and explode
voteText: but there has been at least one instance of a block being left out of an explosion. As far as I can tell
helpfulPercent: there is very little discernable difference from the three difficulty levels
votesHelpful: and it's possible to play songs that are impossible to lose on
votesTotal: even on the hardest difficulty.\n\nIf Turba offered custom BPM and beat offset settings per song (features other software is quite easily able to do)
votesFunny: this game would probably be redeemable. But with the main mechanic of the game broken
commentsCount: it's hardly worth spending your money on."

reviewText:
Turba is sort of a Lumines clone ('Lumines ? What's that ?' Well... do your homework !) but instead of multicolored squares you try and match 3 or more single colored squares. Yes, yes, it's like all those other games (Bejeweled, Puzzle Quest, you name it) but you can also use your own music (everyone knows that my taste in music is excellent ;)). It's a plus for me, especially since it's integrated into the gameplay.
Solid puzzle game right here.

[Rating: 67/100]

reviewText: I'm a big fan of both tile games and music games... and I love when my favorite genres come together.  This one really misses the mark though.  Its not very well put together.  The actions you take don't seem to really even be affected by the music, and the fun factor is quite meh.\n\nWish I could recommend, but just can't.

reviewText: Turba is a music/puzzle game where you match the color blocks to score points while playing one of your favorite music. At first, it was fun cause you play the game while jamming your music. However, it gets real boring quickly. The problem of this game is scoring points. Why you say that? When you start to play, matching the color blocks (3 or more) will give you minimal points. To score big points, you must match the blocks from hearing the beat of the music. That's gonna be difficult, depending the tempo of the music you play. Sure you may score well when playing a slow melody but playing a fast tempo song is gonna be hard.\n\nTurba is an okay game but its not recommend to play forever. There are better music games out there than this one.

reviewText: Generally, in rhythm-based games that have so many of their mechanics based around detecting the beat of a song, you actually want the beat-detection to detect the ever-important beat. When it fails to do this for virtually your entire library - detecting beats that don't exist, consistently skipping beats in a chugging song that has an unchanging beat - and the mechanics of the game don't just reward your attentiveness to the beat but actively punishes you for not keeping with the game's seemingly arbitrary measure of where the beat of your song actually is, then it makes the game...\n\n...basically unplayable.
